educational_objective: Identify pleural effusion by using point-of-care ultrasonography.
question_text: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for shortness of breath. Point-of-care ultrasonography of the lungs is performed. An ultrasound video with the probe placed at the left fifth intercostal space in the posterior axillary line is shown.(Note that there is no sound for this video.)
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
critique: This ultrasound finding is most consistent with a pleural effusion (Option A). The right side of the screen shows the diaphragm (white) moving with respiration. The lung on the left is visible moving in a large collection of fluid, which appears black.A pneumothorax would present with a loss of “lung sliding,” which is the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the parietal pleura seen with respiration. Pneumonia is typically identified on ultrasonography by regions of lung that have a consolidated tissue–like appearance similar to the liver (“hepatization” of the lung). Often these regions are surrounded by focal B lines, an artifact generated by differences in density of the lung parenchyma resulting from increased fluid content. Neither is seen in this study. Pulmonary fibrosis on lung ultrasonography would appear as a thickened, irregular pleural line in addition to a diffuse B-line pattern.
